stem: A 74-year-old client with atrial fibrillation is reporting nausea and 'yellowish' vision. Based on the documentation in the Electrocardiogram & Electrolyte Trend tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Client reporting visual changes and malaise.
Background: History of CHF and Afib. Currently taking Digoxin 0.125mg and Furosemide 40mg daily.
Assessment: Heart rate is 52 (Bradycardia). Yellow halos around lights.
Recommendation: Evaluate for toxicity-inducing triggers.

tabs.title: ECG & Electrolyte Trend
tabs.content:
Assessment ItemCurrent FindingPrevious (2 days ago)
Serum Potassium (K+)2.9 mEq/L (Low)3.8 mEq/L (Normal)
Serum Digoxin1.8 ng/mL1.2 ng/mL
Cardiac RhythmSinus Bradycardia w/ PVCsAfib with RVR

actionOptions.text: Hold the scheduled dose of Digoxin
Administer Potassium Chloride (KCl) IV pigment as prescribed
Administer Furosemide to increase renal clearance
Increase the dose of Digoxin to control the heart rate

rationale.correct: The client is experiencing Digoxin toxicity despite a 'high-normal' drug level because of Hypokalemia (K+ 2.9) (c2). Low potassium sensitizes the heart to the effects of digoxin. The priority is to stop the drug (a1) and correct the potassium deficit (a2). Monitoring for arrhythmias on telemetry (p1) and tracking the K+ recovery (p2) are essential.
clinicalPearls: Digoxin and Potassium compete for the same receptors. Low K+ = More Digoxin binding sites available.
Visual changes (Yellow/Green halos) are a hallmark late sign of toxicity.

questionTrap.trap: Thinking Digoxin is 'fine' because it is 1.8 (under 2.0).
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Levels are IRRELEVANT if the symptoms are present and the potassium is low. Toxicity is clinical, not just numerical.

mnemonic.title: Low K+ High Dig
mnemonic.expansion: If Potassium drops down low, Digoxin's toxic effects will grow.
